byline.contributor: Melissa Eddy and Alison Smale contributed reporting from Berlin, and James Kanter from Brussels.
byline.original: By STEVEN ERLANGER, STEPHEN CASTLE and SEWELL CHAN

abstract: Leaders on both sides of debate over Great Britain's withdrawal from European Union are unsure of when and how country's departure should happen; paralysis highlights EU's difficulty in balancing democratic accountability against its institutional drive to further cause of unity and its inability to act quickly to address crises that regularly undercut confidence among voters.
lead_paragraph: Leaders on both sides of the “Brexit” debate signaled that they wanted continued access to the free-trade zone, though the European Union may have other ideas.

headline.main: Economic Fears Rising, Britain Hopes to Stay in E.U. Market
headline.print_headline: Confusion Over What’s Next Paralyzes British Leadership

snippet: Leaders on both sides of the “Brexit” debate signaled that they wanted continued access to the free-trade zone, though the European Union may have other ideas.
